prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CF+ in the inner galaxy - Sgr sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We trace C+ into diffuse molecular gas and across the interface between atomic and molecular gas by following the fluorine. Fluorine is strongly concentrated into HF whenever H2 is abundant and regions of overlap between C+ and H2 (hence HF) have abundant CF+ after the reaction C+ + HF -> CF+ + H.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We seek to detect 1% absorption in CF+ and HOC+ against ~1 Jy continuum sources with requisite 5:1 S/N, in clouds with linewidth ~5 km/s as is typical of features seen in/near the galactic plane. The S/N criterion here is rms 2 mJy/beam over a typical cloud linewidth of 5 km/s. This is to be distinguished from the much broader ranges over which such absorption features will be detected owing to the galactic velocity field.
Much stronger absorption over broad velocity ranges will be easily detected in HCO+, HCN, etc over much wider velocity ranges owing to blending and line saturation, as shown in figures in the scientific justification. These will be observed with high S/N whenever the weaker CF+ and HOC+ are sought. We have selected additional interesting lines in the same frequency range that can be observed for free : 13CS, NH2CHO, C3H and C3H+.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CF+ in the inner galaxy - W31 G10.6-0.4 and G5.89
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We trace C+ into diffuse molecular gas and the interface between atomic and molecular gas by following the fluorine. Fluorine is strongly concentrated into HF whenever H2 is abundant and regions of overlap between C+ and H2 (hence HF) have abundant CF+ after the reaction C+ + HF -> CF+ + H.

We seek to detect 1% absorption in CF+ and HOC+ against ~1 Jy continuum sources with requisite 5:1 S/N, in clouds with linewidth ~5 km/s as is typical of features seen in/near the galactic plane. These will be observed with high S/N whenever the weaker CF+ and HOC+ are sought. in the same frequency range that can be observed for free : 13CS, NH2CHO, C3H and C3H+.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CF+ in the inner galaxy - B1730-130
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We trace C+ into diffuse molecular gas and the interfaces between atomic and molecular gas by following the fluorine. Fluorine is strongly concentrated into HF whenever H2 is abundant and regions of overlap between C+ and H2 (hence HF) have abundant CF+ after the reaction C+ + HF -> CF+ + H.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We seek to detect 1% absorption in CF+ and HOC+ against ~1 Jy continuum sources with requisite 5:1 S/N, in clouds with linewidth ~5 km/s as is typical of features seen in/near the galactic plane. The S/N criterion here is rms 2 mJy/beam over a typical cloud linewidth of 5 km/s. This is to be distinguished from the much broader ranges over which such absorption features will be detected owing to the galactic velocity field.
Much stronger absorption over broad velocity ranges will be easily detected in HCO+, HCN, etc over much wider velocity ranges owing to blending and line saturation, as shown in figures in the scientific justification. These will be observed with high S/N whenever the weaker CF+ and HOC+ are sought. in the same frequency range that can be observed for free : 13CS, NH2CHO, C3H and C3H+.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Herschel and Planck data confirm the presence of diffuse ISM gas that is not well traced by the usual atomic or molecular probes, ie H I or CO. It can be followed in C+, in emission at 1.9 THz, but we propose a more accessible probe of C+ by following gas-phase fluorine into HF and CF+.
When H2 is present, fluorine concentrates into HF exothermically via F+H2->HF+H and forms CF+ via C+ + HF->CF+ + H, making CF+ the 2nd largest fluorine reservoir where C+ and H2 coexist. Since HF tracks H2, CF+ is a perfect tracer of the H I-> H2 transition.
Recent observations toward the Horsehead and the bright QSOs BLLAC and 3C111 illustrate this in the science case. We propose to use ALMA to perform an exploratory survey of CF+ absorption in the inner galactic plane using well characterized sight-lines towards continuum sources studied in the Herschel PRISMAS survey and other means. We target HOC+ simultaneously because HOC+ forms in the reaction of C+ and H2O. By comparison with the existing data, we will determine the fraction of diffuse gas in molecular form and investigate the relative contributions of atomic, molecular and ionized gas to the C+ budget.
